Confirm with the customer whether the installation was done correctly?
1.All units​ The gas connection must be made with a ¾” gas connection kit.The size of the line is important for volume.
2.If it's NG (Natural Gas), the customer doesn't need to install any regulator. The pressure can be adjusted directly on the combination valvepressure adjustment
3.If it's LP,Verify that the customer has both a 1st and 2nd stage regulator similar to what is shown on the left, or a dual stage regulator that brings the pressure of the tank down to less than 14” W.C. (1/2 PSI) but greater than 10” W.C.The gas valves internal regulator will take it from there​Propane Gas – For all LP gas setups

.​
technician:
Thermopile working principle and fault diagnosis.
1.The Millivolt fryer system runs on an 800mv thermopile.As flame is applied to the thermopile on the unit by the pilot, the thermopile generates 800mv of DC voltage.This voltage is what is used by the valve to hold the pilot open.It is also used by the valve when the thermostat on the unit calls for heat.The thermostat passes the voltage from the thermopile to the valve to open the main gas supply and turn on the burners.
2.If the thermopile is bad or weak, then the unit will not work properly or will work intermittently.​

Pilot will light but when the button is released the pilot goes out？
1.TEST THERMOPILE--Disconnect the thermopile from the unit and test it in open flame.The thermopile should be producing between 750-800mv DC.
2.TEST HIGH LIMIT--Disconnect the high limit from the unit and complete a continuity check on the high limit. You should have continuity between common and normally closed. You should not have continuity between common and normally open unless the oil in the fryer is hotter than 450 degrees. If both above-mentioned parts test fine, then the gas valve will need to be replaced​

Pilot will light and hold but the main burners will not come on？
1.TEST THERMOPILE--Disconnect the thermopile from the unit and test it in open flame.The thermopile should be producing between 750-800mv DC.
2.TEST THERMOSTART--Disconnect the thermostat from the fryer and perform a continuity check across the thermostat when it is off and on. ​​

Pilot lights and main burners fire then shortly after everything shuts off. Or unit heats up a little then everything shuts off？
1.TEST THERMOPILE--Disconnect the thermopile from the unit and test it in open flame. The thermopile should be producing between 750-800mv DC.
2.TEST HIGH-LIMIT--Disconnect the high limit from the unit and complete a continuity check on the high limit. You should have continuity between common and normally closed. You should not have continuity between common and normally open unless the oil in the fryer is hotter than 450 degrees. ​​

Unit heats up once then everything shuts off？
1.TEST HIGH-LIMIT--Turn the unit on and set the thermostat to 350.Temp the oil as the unit heats.If the unit shuts off before reaching 350 this is a high limit issue
2.TEST THERMOSTAT--If the unit goes up to 450 and then shuts off this is a thermostat issue. ​​
Gas Pressure Information

A gas burner works based on Bernoulli’s Principle. Simply put, the jet of fast-moving gas coming out of the orifice, drags the surrounding air into the burner with it. The venturi effect mixes the air with the gas to create the fuel to air mixture that burns when it comes out of the burner holes.

As you increase in elevation the air begins to thin out, there is less oxygen in the air to burn so the flame on the unit is more gas than it is oxygen, this causes the flame to turn orange and produce soot. To counteract this the holes in the orifices on the unit need to be smaller. This restricts the volume of gas coming out of the orifice without slowing the speed at which it comes out. This allows for more air to mix in the burner venturi to keep the flame blue. ​

​All our units are shipped out with “Sea Level” Orifices in them.It is up to the end user's installer to size the orifices on the unit accordingly when the unit is to be installed at elevation.
